Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Could you wear this hairstyle to work?  This might have been what we could have looked like if the c*lonial catastrophe didn‚Äôt happen.I personally can wear this hairstyle, perhaps because I work in the media. However I don‚Äôt see lots of women rocking these kind of styles even in the creative industries. This hairstyle now takes boldness to wear, especially in business. But this used to be our norm. We shouldn‚Äôt need to be brave to be ourselves. What is the biggest barrier?‚ùå Self-regulation ‚ùå Status quoWe talk about stepping out in business or being outside the box. Your hair can make a statement instead of conforming‚Ä¶This was shared on Instagram by 4CHairAfrica.Abi Adamson ‚ÄúThe DEIB Ajagun‚Äùü™¨ Myriah Hampton Tashara Parker, MA Paige Lewin üåêGloria Tabi #hair #african #womeninbusiness

Post Text: This is major. How do I show up in 2024?

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: My daughter turned 18 yesterday! I‚Äôm not allowed to post without her permission shh don‚Äôt tell her. She was my inspiration to create World Afro Day¬Æ I wanted her to grow up embracing her Afro hair and every barrier broken down that told her that her hair wasn‚Äôt good enough in every area of life. I love this young woman and it‚Äôs been a pleasure raising her. I hope that there are people out there that want to change workplaces for the next generation too.I made a promise to myself this year that the whole of me would show up on LinkedIn. I am a mother, child of God, carer, TV Producer, founder, CEO, daughter, friend, sister, colleague, landlord, global influencer and leader‚Ä¶ Carol Pyke taught me that the whole of me walks into every room, I am not one dimension, I am multidimensional. Ponder: do parents especially mothers feel comfortable about speaking about their kids on LinkedIn? Mark Cuban on Shark Tank was really open about his kids learning through business. I still second guess whether to post about motherhood‚Ä¶but this is a happy moment I wanted to share. Georgina Wilson FRSA

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: What a fitting end to my first week of Black History Month. This is my day job at ITV Good Morning Britain and I got to feature another great business Soul Cap Tokunbo Ahmed Michael Charles Chapman doing great things for the community and the film was presented by the multi talented Radzi Chinyanganya.Swimming is a really good example of what works for the majority of swimmers was not welcoming or inclusive of people with Afro hair. It‚Äôs the same in business, education and nearly all aspects of society. What could you learn from attitudes in swimming about your own attitudes in business?

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Would this hairstyle close the deal?I think I would be mesmerised by whatever she was selling! Wouldn‚Äôt it have been great if we had been taught to rock our Afros at work like this? This style is so simple and effective but statistics show that we could be discriminated against because of our natural hair. However, I am a firm believer that what is for you cannot be taken from you.There is power in being an original. What if millions of girls and women had grown up with hair commercials like this?Afros in the workplace?‚úÖ YES‚ùå NOPosted on Instagram by @ivonenum Myriah Hampton Paige Lewin Tashara Parker, MA #womeninbusiness #worldafroday

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Sending some love to Halle Berry looking ‚Äòbeauty ‚Äòfro.‚Äô She has just posted this and told the haters to complain to her man, who loves her look. I remember when she was pulled apart on the red carpet when she rocked a natural style, people posted such hurtful comments and my heart went out to her. I am glad that she wants to show this side of her hair again because too often our hair is criticised if everything isn‚Äôt sleek and smooth. We can rock it like this too and love the gift of versatility. Anyway actresses experience so much scrutiny in their profession, it would be great to support them because some of them are really flying the flag for our natural hair.Our hair is excellent, professional and beautiful. Are your ready to change your industry 15th September World Afro Day - Workplace? Link in bio. Tashara Parker, MA Akima Paul Lambert Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: I grew up without a mother‚Ä¶and I still don‚Äôt have a mother.‚ùå No she is not dead but this post isn‚Äôt about her‚Ä¶‚úÖ I have some amazing news to share about being a mother (you may already know this but I didn‚Äôt).Mother‚Äôs Day gives me a lot to reflect on each year and I am grateful for the amazing experience of raising this beautiful soul Estelle M. Despite a tough financial climate Brits were projected to spend ¬£1.7bn on Mother‚Äôs Day this year an increase of 1.1%. There is a massive commercial focus on this day but for most it‚Äôs a deeply personal time and especially those without their mothers or have never been able to become mothers and those still trying to be one, it has mixed emotions.There is always something to learn in life and I love new information that makes you think about something familiar in a whole new way. When I found some new information about motherhood on social media my journalist training kicked in. Is rhis really true? So I did some more research and this is what I found:‚úÖ The fetus transfers cells to the mother not just mother to fetus‚úÖ Cellls from the fetus can stay in the mother for decades! ‚úÖ Cells from the fetus go to sites of injury or disease in the mother to help! Wow I was just blown away by this information you can read more here. https://lnkd.in/ec-s6AfJScience can often give us facts but they are not so good at explaining why. For me, this fact had me in awe that God put this design feature into pregnancy, a wonderful exchange between mother and child on a cellular level. It‚Äôs up to us to keep the exchange going. Keep learning and I hope you had a great Mother‚Äôs Day.Shout out to #linkedincommunity mums Paulette Watson MBA Global Tech Disruptor Dr. Patti O'Brien-Richardson Akima Paul Lambert Denese Chikwendu, MAPM, CertCoach, MA, BA (Hons) Georgina Wilson FRSA Gloria Tabi Sarah-Jane Crawford Jane Powell Dr. Jacqueline Harding - Vallance #learning #mothersday

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: SAVE THE DATE 1pm BST, June 7, 2023.I'm super excited to be finally be able to speak about how you can be a part of World Afro Day 2023. This is the time to turn history in our favour!

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Liberte, egalite, fraternite!One MP Olivier SERVA is putting forward a bill to end Afro hair discrimination in France! This is great to see because change needs to happen and France has the largest population of African descendants in Europe. Estimates there are 3-5 million Black people but France refuses to collect racial data so will they acknowledge hair discrimination?Anyone who doesn‚Äôt yet understand Afro hair discrimination, please reflect that African descendants need laws about our hair to be considered equal human beings! This liberation movement is growing around the world. Lawmakers and business leaders are being asked to be part of change. Your thoughts Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Akima Paul Lambert Jane Powell D. Wendy Greene Patti O'Brien-Richardson, PhD Emmanuel Asuquo - TV Financial Adviser Are changes happening in your workplace? #change #leaders #france #blackhair #afrohair

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Today I am grateful for the fantastic contributors to World Afro Day¬Æ Levi Roots first got involved at our awards ceremony in 2018 and returned this year.Scarlette Douglas has supported us with her presenting skill since 2019 and always posts her crown on the day.Tashara Parker, MA first became involved in 2021 at our schools event The Big Hair Assembly.  This time she flew over 4000 miles to co-host the event.Georgina Wilson FRSA has supported from the sidelines but became our official business training partner in 2023, sharing her expertise but I have known her for 9 years. These are just a few of the names that share the vision and know that this is a journey of epic proportions. We don‚Äôt know when we will get to the Promised Land of hair freedom but at least we are on the move.How many companies need to start this journey? There is no freedom at work unless you include our Afro hair! You can still see the Workplace Hair acceptance Panel on the World Afro Day YouTube channel. Free learning. #education #training #workplace

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Another reason why it‚Äôs not just hair but in some cases life and death!Wow so our hairstyles can cause misdiagnosis in X-rays? I‚Äôm glad that this work is being done but what does this mean for all the X-rays we have been getting so far? Does anyone know about the UK experience? A simple question Joel Bervell why are patients not asked to put their hair up away from interference? #healthcare #equality

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: OvercomerThe harder the journey the greater the outcome. World Afro Day¬Æ was one of the most difficult things to launch in my life back in 2017. However this year is proving to be very challenging in different ways but I‚Äôm sharing this now so that when September 15th comes you will celebrate the victory with me. If you are reading this, I have already prayed for you have a blessed day.

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: What's in a name?How did you choose your brand name? What about Nike, Amazon and Google? I recently watched the documentary Air, about Michael Jordon and Nike creating Air Jordon. I recommend it from a business and branding perspective. It was fascinating to watch the story of how Nike was the underdog and how one product changed their fortunes and the Jordon family.The name World Afro Day¬Æ does what it says on the tin and I was googling images this morning and found this one. Definitely one of the best images used to celebrate the day. I would actually say searching World Afro Day images is good for your soul! So many happy images of Black people enjoying their God-given hair. I think illustrator Vashti Harrison also captures this spirit in her work. I found this on a website from Cameroon, plus I saw an article on an Indian website too. World Afro Day is acknowledged in six continents!Have you trademarked your brand? Before I launched World Afro Day in 2017 I registered it as a trademark. I believed it would be celebrated all over the world. Now, I have to think carefully about new things I create and whether to register the name because I have been legally challenged before.Have you spoken to trademark lawyers? Defending your trademark is not as straightforward as you might think. You have to decide when your trademark is infringed and what you want to spend your time and money on protecting. Thanks to Akima Paul Lambert and Hogan Lovells, who provide World Afro Day with pro bono support. World Afro Day is not like Black History Month, you can't do whatever you want with our name! So I will have to write to a few picture agencies today to get them to stop selling images using our name! But what a privilege to create a brand that makes people smile and celebrate all over the world. Also it unites people from different backgrounds so this is the part I want to harness as a business. I hope this image makes you smile today. Did you know there is a professor of branding? Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt have you seen Air? What did you think when you first heard of World Afro Day? Jane Powell any thoughts? You work with lots of brands. #branding #business #people #happy

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Giving thanks in tough timesLife has thrown me a curveball that no one can prepare you for. I can‚Äôt avoid it, I can‚Äôt remove it so I have to go through it. Sometimes it is overwhelming, sometimes it is sad, sometimes it is scary‚Ä¶Yes I share my successes here but I‚Äôm also sharing my trials and we all have them.March has 31 Days and I will be intentional with my gratitude daily sometimes I will post about it but I will be doing it anyway. God says to give thanks in all things so here goes‚Ä¶whatever March throws at me, I will be grateful not for the issue but for the many good things in my life. Day 1 - today I woke up without any disturbance from the night before. Thank youTo anyone reading this please have the best day you can and find something to be thankful for. I hope you do.

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: I am preparing our first Employer Hair Report for World Afro Day¬Æ 2023,which is causing me to reflect on this journey of changing our hair to get jobs. My daughter represents the first person in 5 generations to be free in our family! I am celebrating her freedom today while working on groundbreaking changes for workplaces so everyone can be free. If some people aren‚Äôt free to be themselves, then no one is free.Companies need to end hair discrimination because ‚Äúwith great power comes great responsibility.‚Äù Employees shouldn‚Äôt need to be superheroes to wear their African hair at work. We should just be ourselves, which is good enough. Would you change the world for your kids or maybe just your workplace? We have one event for employees and a training event for employers. Link in comments join our amazing supporters Tashara Parker, MA Scarlette Douglas Levi Roots Akima Paul Lambert Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Emmanuel Asuquo - TV Financial Adviser Jane Powell Patti O'Brien-Richardson, PhD D. Wendy Greene Alice Dearing OLY Estelle M. #blackhair #professional #traininganddevelopment

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Setting your own standards!Women with Afro hair have been conforming to straight hair and laid edges to feel ‚Äòdone‚Äô ‚Äòprofessional‚Äô and appropriate for work. It doesn‚Äôt have to be this way because we have the most versatile hair in the world.World Afro Day¬Æ recent Employer Hair Attitudes survey showed that a woman with straight hair was considered more appropriate by 20 percentage points! So the discrimination is real but do we keep complying or push back?My hairstyle doesn‚Äôt have the usual gloss and definition of some of my other styles but I still look stylish. Would someone without Afro hair even notice these things or do we put these restrictions on ourselves?‚úÖ Do we have more external pressure?‚úÖ Do we put more pressure on ourselves?What do you think is up to us to set the standard for our own hair? Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Denese Chikwendu, MAPM, CertCoach, MA, BA (Hons) Tashara Parker, MA Paige Lewin Gloria Tabi Sarah-Jane Crawford Sharlene Monique Kadisha J. Georgina Wilson FRSA Carole Pyke MCIM Carol Stewart MSc, FIoL

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: We are in transition and I'm not just talking about hair...There will be some major news in 2024 and we will keep pressing forward for the freedom of Afro hair. Channel 4 is now the only major UK broadcaster never to have covered World Afro Day¬Æ, which is strange because we have been creating impact for seven years. Hopefully someone there will read this. Making Afro hair acceptance a mainstream issue in the media spotlight has been one of our major achievements since we launched World Afro Day¬Æ.  Anyway Channel 5 stepped up in 2023 with this feature on Afro hair discrimination in the workplace. For the full details on the employment research visit our website. Let's make Afro hair accepted in the workplace, it's the 21st century! Thanks to Anastasia Chikezie Paulette Watson MBA Global Tech Disruptor Tashara Parker, MA featured in this piece.#professional #blackhair #research

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Read about our historic breakthrough for Afro hair equality in UK Schools.

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: ‚ÄúA woman who cuts her hair is about to change her life.‚Äù Coco ChanelThis time April 2021 I did the big chop. For many women the idea of cutting off their hair is a complete no no and I was one of them but somehow coming out of lockdown I was ready to face the world differently. African heritage women experience more scrutiny than any other group, when it comes to their hair. Long or short we are asked too many questions about our hair and the worst is when we are touched without our permission. However, the only way to change this is through conversation and education. World Afro Day¬Æ has been on this mission for seven years, sometimes changing hearts and minds one person, one school or one organisation at a time.Stepping out of my comfort zone with my hair, maybe helped me to be more bold in other ways. Some women do regular big chops and I do think that they can be bolder than other women. They do not need to be as conventional. Yet African heritage women can look stunning with short hair. It doesn‚Äôt have to be the big chop but stepping out of your comfort zone with hair can challenge you on many levels. Lockdown allowed many people to go natural, grow longer hair, bigger fros and become less conformist.Some hairstyles challenge your own beliefs, confidence and identity as well as dealing with other people‚Äôs perceptions. Maybe my hair reflects my attitudes to risk‚Ä¶I am courageous and in business and life that is good. What made you do a big hair change? Styling thanks to hair legend Anastasia Chikezie Samuel Kasumu Scarlette Douglas Paige Lewin üåêGloria Tabi Carol Stewart MSc, FIoL #lockdown #womeninbusiness #bigchop #hair

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Monday I was speaking in suppprt of the French Parliament.Today I attended the UK Parliament.Shh someone might think that I am up to something‚Ä¶Thanks to the force of fruitfulness Cherron Inko-Tariah MBE for the invitation.Are corporates, SMEs and DEI award winning companies ready to embrace Afro hair at work? We know the majority aren‚Äôt so it‚Äôs time for change. Saluting my sisters who shake things up! Guylaine Conquet Tashara Parker, MA Myriah Hampton Beverley Bramwell Carol Stewart MSc, FIoL Carole Pyke MCIM Beverley Samuel Akima Paul Lambert Gloria Tabi Sharlene Monique Denese Chikwendu, MAPM, CertCoach, MA, BA (Hons) Shanaz Mahomed Dion Johnson- The Board Level POWER Coach

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: What do these three women have in common? They showcase the versatility and beauty of natural Afro hair. Their skills talents and abilities are not in their hair so why would companies choose the straight hairstyle as a standard of professionalism? It‚Äôs illogical and discriminatory but this has been business as usual since the early 1900s, when we started to straighten our hair with hot combs. Hair discrimination originates as an employment issue because African diaspora people straightened their hair for better job prospects.If you believe all three women should be able to be employed on merit not on hairstyle. If you believe that Africans looking African is our heritage and that this should be respected at work, then join the movement World Afro Day - Workplace, 15 September.It‚Äôs time for change, it‚Äôs time for employers to get trained, it‚Äôs time to be ourselves. New employer research released on World Afro Day! Will you be there? Event links in comments.#training #research #companyculture #legal Get in touch about your workplace hair stories and let‚Äôs change this together! Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Have you seen the BHM magazine packed full of great features celebrating our sisters? Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Who knew that the law could be so exciting...Today I joined a member of the French Parliament Olivier SERVA (bottom left in photo) to give evidence towards a new law against hair discrimination in France. I got this opportunity because of Guylaine Conquet who has been doing great work campaigning to change the law in France. This work is gaining momentum and if they pass the law it might be the first country  in the world to have a national law! The CROWN Act is only at the state level so all eyes are on France now... Even African and Caribbean nations have been slow to legislate against hair discrimination, although it is needed just as much in these nations as anywhere else. The minister for education and social development Dee-ann Kentish-Rogers also pioneered this work in Anguilla by introducing a new hair code in 2022. From my experience leading World Afro Day¬Æ, people of African descent really want these laws to rectify an issue that has been hidden for far too long.Let's be honest, workplaces will not change fast enough until the law changes. However, the research clearly shows that people with Afro hair have been denied economic opportunity for hundreds of years because they are deemed to have the 'wrong type' of hair. Why didn't you get the job? I wouldn't straighten my hair to look more European...does this make any sense, when you're an African? Companies need to understand that being ourselves, brings the best results!Anyone else looking forward to a new law to end Afro hair discrimination? Tashara Parker, MA D. Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Lessons from 2023‚úÖBe grateful at all times. It‚Äôs been a really tough year but I was invited to a Black History Month event at UK Parliament and got to enlarge my network.‚úÖKnowledge is still power. Our Workplace Hair Acceptance report was pioneering and we can build on this new evidence for the future.‚úÖ There are no mistakes just learning opportunities and ways to grow. My personality is to win so I find this one hard. ‚úÖHealth & Wellbeing is a life and business priority. We need to speak more about what we are doing in this area on LinkedIn. I did way too much work in 2023 and I need to take care of myself and loved ones better in 2024.‚úÖSharing more personal information on LinkedIn that shapes my leadership and why I am committed to my vision of Afro hair acceptance in the workplace. I am a private person but life has real challenges that when we overcome them, it can help others.‚úÖForgiveness is perhaps the hardest thing we can ever do. Has someone disappointed you this year? Leave it in 2023 forgive and be free to embrace 2024 with everything you have!‚úÖChristmas is still a time to believe in miracles. If you have lost someone who was a big part of Christmas, then this can keep you in the past‚Ä¶ After seven years of lost Christmases we finally had a family Christmas to bring comfort and joy.I can‚Äôt say I liked 2023 but I am here, you are here so I am grateful and by God‚Äôs grace I hope you and I have an amazing 2024.#grateful #2023year #family

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Wow wow wow this young woman Coco Gauff has inspired the world! I love this picture because it took her family to raise her to become US champion at 19 years old. I will use a little bit of this inspiration as I keep the faith with 5 Days to go! Anyone who has a dream keep going and I look forward to reading about it! Beverley Samuel Carole Pyke MCIM

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: It‚Äôs August 2023 and I am opening a dialogue with businesses about ending hair discrimination, which is an employment issue. So does your company know about this and are they ready to be part of the solution on World Afro Day¬Æ 15th September? Let‚Äôs not hide this anymore, some companies are ready to listen and some companies want to keep things the same. But we can all play a small part, let someone in HR know about our new training for employers or join our event for employees. Visit our website for more link in comments.What else do you think can we do to change workplaces? #training #business #dei

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Slavery was tradition too. Well done for Mel B and Geri for calling this out back in the 90s. Unfortunately it is still part of the Netherlands culture. There is no excuse for this behaviour, life must be tough growing up in the Netherlands with African ancestry. Why did this hateful tradition get so well preserved in the Netherlands and other parts of Europe? Thanks Mary Waweru for sharing this clip. I wonder how many popstars today would be as vocal.Sometimes progress feels like an illusion‚Ä¶Janine van Throo #netherlands #change #equality

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: I‚Äôm excited about this hire Myriah Hampton.Great people are the beating heart of any business but World Afro Day¬Æ is more than a business it is making history. People relate to World Afro Day on many levels but some people really get the depth of it and this is not determined by race. Supporters can come from all backgrounds and they will get in the trenches with you and walk the extra mile with you like Jane Powell.Back to Myriah Hampton who is an outstanding PhD student soon to become Dr Hampton. She wanted to work for us in any capacity and for now she is volunteering.‚úÖHer reference process was exemplary. I sent the email request out yesterday morning and within 4 hours and UK/USA time difference, three excellent references came back! I think this is testament to her calibre and reputation. Welcome Myriah we are looking forward to working with you on some exciting projects for 2024.#womeninbusiness #academic #volunteering

A global training event to end hair discrimination in millions of businesses.Is your company clued up or clueless about this much needed change? ITV News did some powerful reports with local case studies, plus Levi Roots and myself. Check out the film and article belowThanks to the speakers at our launch #linkedinaudioevent yesterday Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Georgina Wilson FRSA Jane Powell D. Wendy Greene Paulette Watson MBA Global Tech Disruptor Tashara Parker, MA and all the audience who gave us their feedback. Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Women wear so many hats‚Ä¶Here are just a few of mine: CEO, TV Producer, mother and more recently carer to a sick relative, which you can‚Äôt be trained for. To anyone out there doing this, I think this role is harder than being a parent so please take some time for self-care. This also means that I am not always sure how I can continue World Afro Day¬Æ but it is so close to my heart, I literally had so much pain giving birth to it. I still want it to succeed. Yesterday at church the message was not to draw back into survival mode, there is more ‚Äòrise up & build‚Äô. I have been retreating recently but also my dreams won‚Äôt leave me either. This time we need to do things differently and here on #linkedin you can help build something good. So keep watching this space‚Ä¶Is anyone ready to go BIG? Akima Paul Lambert Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Paulette Watson MBA Global Tech Disruptor Gloria Tabi Nancy Adimora Denese Chikwendu, MAPM, CertCoach, MA, BA (Hons) D. Wendy Greene Tashara Parker, MA Georgina Wilson FRSA Kadisha J. Lere Fisher Paige Lewin Sarah-Jane Crawford Estelle M. I am ‚Äòthankful‚Äô (challenge continues) for meeting up with some GMTV colleagues for a social escape for a few hours. I have known them for over 20 years! We had a lovely ‚ÄòBrown Girls‚Äô afternoon tea with Donna Bernard Camille Solomon Esther Kuku  (MCIPR) We are all professional women and mothers, who still have dreams so we encouraged one another. #iwd2024womenleadingtheway #selfcare

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: What a day! My business breakfast with Georgina Wilson FRSA highlighted some great conversations about ‚Äòbeing ourselves‚Äô in the workplace. In the train station I ran into a female HR consultant with locs!Then I got to Bankside Hotel and had this exchange with the staff and management about Afro hair. It‚Äôs good to get out there and I can‚Äôt wait to share with everyone about our plans for World Afro Day¬Æ workplace. #management #hotelindustry #business #afrohair What are your experiences of the hospitality industry and Afro hair? Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: If you need inspiration this morning check out Demisha Jennings post. She is celebrating her freedom to wear braids at work with hundreds of positive comments. So I ask you is the tide turning for Afrocentric hair in the workplace?There are a lot of ignorant comments in the true sense that white people didn‚Äôt know that Afro hair was an issue‚Ä¶really. Therein lies another problem but they all seem open to learn, which is encouraging. Thanks Rachael Jones CMgr FCMI Jane Powell Lisa Maria Mai  for supporting change. #work #change #womeninbusiness #hair

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: I have to admit that I have let myself go‚Ä¶I used to be a champion runner. Here I am collecting the Surrey Championship relay cup for 100 and 200m. Athletics was great for discipline and a winning attitude. I had a great time with these girls, 3 out of 4 of our relay team were called Michelle!‚úÖ I was even inspired by USA champion Val√©rie Briscoe Hooks because she could do a thousand sit ups so I followed suit!‚ùå Today I cannot really do press ups any more and I started off with just 30 sit ups‚Ä¶Although I have fallen a long way from my best, I will start off small and get better.‚úÖ I felt in my spirit that taking up sit ups and press ups would be good for my discipline. I haven‚Äôt done them regularly for 19 years, before I had my daughter. Mind, body and spirit are related. I am coming into alignment.‚úÖ World Afro Day¬Æ will be launching our 2024 theme soon and all this is all relevant.‚úÖ I am still a champion in some areas of my life and I want to become a champion in new areas. My teen spirit which picked up that cup is still in me. I am just running different types of races and I am doing different types of events but a winning attitude is always needed. Carole Pyke MCIM Michelle Pierre-Carr Michelle Moore MA BA Is there something from your youth, which can help you succeed in business today?#winningattitude #youth #womeninbusiness

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: I‚Äôm thankful today that World Afro Day matters to people of all backgrounds. I think people assume that only people with Afro hair get it but for the last seven years I have worked with people of all colours and nationalities.Truth is truth, straight hair should not determine better opportunities in the workplace.Straight hair should not determine better treatment at school but the global system has operated counter to these truths for over 150 years.I passionately want to see change and this is why I understand this mother‚Äôs gratitude for the small wins, which can sometimes seem huge.What small win could you make in your school or company towards Afro hair? Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Patti O'Brien-Richardson, PhD D. Wendy Greene Paulette Watson MBA Global Tech Disruptor Ross Morrison McGill

Wendy Greene and to those behind the scenes making this happen.I was honoured to be asked to support in a small way.

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: What sort of impact do you want to make in 2024? I am really excited to be preparing to make a presentation to a major British institution, employer, regulator and global leader. Any ideas who it is?Finance is the clue...drop your answers below. I have created a quiz which will be interactive and thought provoking.Tip: Don't afraid to be bold and different in order to make an impact.Does your workplace need a quiz like this to understand Afro hair discrimination? I will also be speaking about our Workplace Hair Acceptance Report. You can read about this on our website www.worldafroday.com. I hope that you will come back later this week to see which workplace it was. Fact: Finance and Insurance are the worst industries for Afro hair discrimination. (source: Workplace Hair Acceptance Report 2023)In the lines of a song: "Do you know where you're going to...?" Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: What is it all for?I find myself asking the big questions in life again. Am I living my purpose and what does that look like? How does my relationship with money influence my outcomes. There is so much to do and what next?We are all living on one of these three levels according to the book Purpose Driven Life:- survival - success- significance I think I straddle between significance and success. World Afro Day¬Æ has certainly achieved significance but is it a success materially?2024 is not yet clear and yesterday one door closed and another one opened. This next door has major significance but it doesn‚Äôt make any money. I know God has given me purpose in what I am doing and it‚Äôs not just about me.There is another project tbc which involves my heart and because of Yinka Ewuola I am structuring it in a way to make money. I always lead with my heart but I need to act with my financial head too. It‚Äôs an exciting and much needed immersion experience for African diaspora women but women and businesses of all types can still support. I hope I get to go on that journey with you or your business. Anyway feeling philosophical this morning. Which level are you living on? Carol Stewart MSc, FIoL Carole Pyke MCIM G√©raldine Poukens Myriah Hampton Pamela Aculey Denese Chikwendu, MAPM, CertCoach, MA, BA (Hons)

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Meetings that change your life‚Ä¶We spend so much time in meetings but some meetings will be dates that you remember forever: first big sponsor, first regulator, first multinational, first invitation to Downing Street.Today was my introductory book meeting with Nancy Adimora and we are beyond excited to be crafting my first book. 2024 has so much more in store for me than I pictured at the start of the year. I couldn‚Äôt quite see it through the turbulent times that I am in. ‚úÖ Don‚Äôt be afraid to change it up. You will be seeing some new things from me this year but letting go of some of the old is hard because I care so much and I want to help children too.‚úÖ Allow the good to make way for the great. Thanks Denese Chikwendu, MAPM, CertCoach, MA, BA (Hons) for helping me to see that.‚úÖ Get yourself around people who are on a success level that you want to get to. Candace Jun√©e Armour is showing other business women how to take their business to six figures so I am part of her ‚ÄúPray for your business challenge‚Äù BIG THANK YOU to the people who have sent DMs, left voice notes and called to check in on me. I appreciate your support. Pamela Aculey Subira Jones Mathurini Visakan (MCIM) Sarah-Jane Crawford Lere Fisher Gloria Tabi and everyone else too.#meetings #iwd2024 #newbusiness

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: I got to celebrate the amazing Georgina Wilson FRSA and the 10 year anniversary of BUD Leaders. I was drawn to this poster of her as a fearless leader. I learned from her speech that as a very young child she was inspired to help others, after receiving a ‚Äúno.‚Äù She has now turned around her own hurt and loss into victory. ‚ÄúI will never let someone take my power again‚Äù she declared as an eight year old child. Now her whole life‚Äôs mission is empowering global majority women through BUD Leaders.The conference was no ordinary event because she is no ordinary leader. There was energy, power and synergy in the room. People didn‚Äôt want to leave and everyone asked for more, next year, next one, when, Georgina was asked‚Ä¶ But as the wise woman she is, she didn‚Äôt move with the crowd and circumstances, she will commit to what aligns with her vision.The room was full of leaders, who are changemakers. ‚úÖ Tip: The digital age cannot replace the power of networking.#BUDevent2024 #BUDCX2 BUD Leaders

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: What's not to love about Afro textured hair and styles? Many workplaces have set ideas about neatness, smartness and professionalism, which are biased towards European presentation. These outdated ideas disadvantage people of African descent in our careers so it is time for a change. Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt is a highly qualified academic, professional and professor speaking at our #linkedinaudioevent tomorrow 1-2pm BST, June 7. Link in comments and bio.Would your workplace employ him or turn him away based on his hair? How many businesses miss out on talented people and are potentially breaking the law?Your business can either be for or against liberation in the workplace for African descendents.  #people #change #careers #law

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Afro gymnasts: how often do you see this?It‚Äôs important that Afro hair is associated with excellent standards! Gymnastics like many professions have promoted grooming standards based on straight European hair and this has mean‚Äôt hiding Afro hair or risking their health with hair relaxers.Some might see an untamed Afro hairstyle. I see a young man operating with feeedom, boldness and achieving high standards based on his skills and not his hair. I love how Gen Z are not going by the old playbook. My daughter is part of this generation but we have a responsibility to make the path easier for them. Like the Olympics we carry the torch to pass on so let‚Äôs change our professions and industries to accept that Afro coily curly hair is the standard for the majority of Africans. When a gymnast reaches the highest level they create an original move which is named after them. You can bring your own style, flare and ingenuity to your workplace. My signature move is World Afro Day¬Æ but you can add your move too! Business is often about creating something new or improving on the existing way, which is similar to gymnastics‚Ä¶I have something coming for 2024.The Paris Olympics are round the corner and as a former athlete I love the sports but as a textured hair advocate I love to watch the hair too. üòâ One of the most famous female athletes on the planet Sha‚ÄôCarri Richardson has been sporting her Afro too along with many other athletes. I wonder if this year we will see something extra special or less extra and more natural‚Ä¶at the Olympics.Myriah Hampton Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Pamela Aculey Michelle Moore MA BA Akima Paul Lambert Carole Pyke MCIM #ParisOlympics #professional #hair

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: My Monday post is caught in LinkedIn no man‚Äôs land! So here I go again‚Ä¶This is officially my gratitude week, it‚Äôs been a tough year but I am choosing to respond with gratitude. I don‚Äôt know what World Afro Day will do next‚Ä¶Harvard Health Publishing: ‚Äú‚Ä¶being grateful also helps people connect to something larger than themselves as individuals ‚Äî whether to other people, nature, or a higher power.‚ÄùI am incredibly thankful to God for seven years of World Afro Day¬Æ and to the millions of people who have shared this special day with me. Theme: art I am thankful for the wonderful art that is created for WAD. My imagination started this day so when people create something in return, it‚Äôs like a lovely loop. Thank you Creative Mama Che for this craft. If you‚Äôre a parent or in education I hope that you enjoy this post creativity is part of business. Beverley Samuel Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Carole Pyke MCIM Mina Prince MCIPD Dr. Jacqueline Harding - Vallance Jordan Ignatius Sharlene Monique Ross Morrison McGill

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: I am so glad that Sharon Thomas plans to highlight hair discrimination at her legal conference. We need to be the change to create environments where we can thrive!  Let‚Äôs hope other conferences leaders follow suit. We can‚Äôt just ask society and companies to change and be inclusive, if we are not setting the pace ourselves.The legal landscape is changing regarding Afro hair discrimination in the USA and France. World Afro Day¬Æ plans to address this in UK law too. Isn‚Äôt it better for your company reputation to learn willingly instead of being forced by the law? What are your conference experiences? Have Afro hair barriers been included? Our research and other reports clearly show that this is an issue in workplaces.#conference #legal #change

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Do you know about trailblazer Una Marson? Her great accomplishments are in this eye opening documentary but it didn‚Äôt escape me that despite her skills, talent and abilities she was criticised because her Afro hair wasn‚Äôt quite good enough. Sound familiar? I spoke about her at a recent employer workshop educating them about hair discrimination. Women of today wearing their natural hair in the workplace experience what Una did in the 1930s! We will be exploring this and new Employer research 15th September World Afro Day - Workplace. Have you got your tickets? Is your company doing the right thing to end this? Employer training eventEmployee empowerment eventLinks in commentsJuanita Rosenior BA. Postgrad. hope to see you there. #training #broadcaster #blackhair #professional

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: The most beautiful skin‚Ä¶People of African descent have the most variety of shades and when I was at a barbecue yesterday, I couldn‚Äôt but help compliment a Black woman on her skin. Some brown skin actually glows it‚Äôs like irresescent and it is captivating. The tanning industry bottle and sell what we naturally have. It‚Äôs an absolute lie that we have been made to think that our skin is ugly or inferior. There are lies and there is truth.

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Mondays don‚Äôt have to be all serious.I was at the amazing BUD Leaders conference on Friday. I met some inspirational leaders Dr Carlton Brown and Lere Fisher is the clean and cheaper version to Kevin Hart, if you want someone to host your event he‚Äôs just as funny! Although BUD has a focus on global majority women it was really good to see men there and to be in a room full of progressive business people. I‚Äôm really looking forward to reading the Black Business Magazine after Justice Williams MBE hosted our panel.Then Colin Tomlin from Pitch Black magazine was also there. How great to have two platforms showcasing Black British entrepreneurship.Thanks to Georgina Wilson FRSA for building a movement challenging us all to lead change. I look forward to her next chapter.A bit of a caption quiz below, what am I doing in this picture? A completely professional act, clean answers only in the comments. Damilola Okeke Samantha Fray Simi J. Jacqueline Shepherd Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Dr. Jacqueline Harding - Vallance #entrepreneurship #BUDEVENT24 #BUDCX2 BUD Leaders

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: You may never have heard of Afro hair discrimination and your company may be doing absolutely nothing about it. This is why featuring on BBC Radio Five Live is so important  for changing attitudes in business and the public.There is so much more to say, so if your company could be inadvertently breaking the law or your company could be creating a hierarchy of Eurocentric appearance in your workplace. Then please get in touch and be a part of long overdue change. Also, don't just take my word for it, we had the best experts at World Afro Day 2023 event. Emmanuel Asuquo - TV Financial Adviser Jane Powell Prof. Jonathan A.J. Wilson PhD DLitt Patti O'Brien-Richardson, PhD Paulette Watson MBA Global Tech Disruptor Levi Roots Scarlette Douglas Tashara Parker, MA D. Wendy Greene Thanks Jenny 'Shine' Steel #journalism #blackhair #blackwomeninbusiness

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: The momentum is building but don‚Äôt keep it to yourself. Remember workplaces need to know that change is coming to accept Afro hair in the workplace. Lessons to learn- speak to HR- speak to Employee groups- speak to the C-suite The new research will be relevant to every business. Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: If you have a goal do you let the weather stop you?So good old English rain scuppered my walk this morning but no I would not be defeated. I dug out my weighted hula hoop buried under the ladder, wiped it down and got hooping! (Clearly I haven‚Äôt used it much since I bought it years ago).‚úÖYes there are business lessons in this because doing new or different things is good for your brain.‚úÖThe hoop dropped many times in the beginning but I kept going and I got my rhythmn back.‚úÖHealthy body and healthy mind is good for your business. ‚úÖThis is research for World Afro Day¬Æ 2024 announcement soon.‚úÖ10 minutes of weighted hula hooping daily can help improve core strength, stability and coordination.I was the best hopper at school. I plan to keep it up Happy Froday.#health #mind #business

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: If you missed it earlier this is my gratitude week. Studies show many benefits for being grateful physically, mentally and spiritually.World Afro Day¬Æ has an international appeal beyond the English language. The diversity of language is not often an opportunity that many small businesses can take advantage of but happy to take any advice on this.Brazil is a supporter of World Afro Day and I have a soft spot for this country, there is so much untapped potential. Below is a post that goes into a lot of detail to help people in Brazil understand the importance of the day. I would love to do more here one day. #international #exports #brazil

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Investing in yourself cannot be emphasised enough in entrepreneurship. Carole Pyke MCIM is effervescent about life and working with you. I have found that no problem is too big because she will always reframe it so that you can win! I have used her before and will do so again because I know I have more to offer and she can help me get there!

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Why did this go viral? 95,000+ views What is professional hair?Maybe the truth that nothing is actually wrong with our hair and our African heritage struck a chord with people. I was professionally dressed and my hair topped off my look but yet this expression of hair is still not the norm in workplaces all over the world! This World Afro Day¬Æ 15th September everyone is invited to be part of change at our events 1. Big Hair Assembly for children2. Training event for employers3. Empowerment event for employeesI hope you will help us make history on 15th September. Join us at World Afro Day - Workplace (employees) link in comments.

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: Has anyone had this WhatsApp Business problem. My account is stolen and I am locked out so don‚Äôt respond to any messages from me on WhatsApp This billion dollar company is so huge but the help pages are ineffectual they don‚Äôt even address my problem. What is happening to my data and all the people I know connected to me?Please let me know if anyone can help? This is awful now I realise why people have left it Simeon Quarrie any ideas?

Author: Michelle De Leon
Post Text: It‚Äôs that Friday feeling to roll up at work wearing your crown. World Afro Day¬Æ has important research coming your way that every employer needs to pay attention to 15 September. Afro hair is an employment issue that needs to be addressed in 2023. This has taken a long time but we want to be free to be ourselves at work so will your company lead or drag your heels?Employees we are here to support and empower you at our event on 15 September details in the comments.Video description: black woman walks down then street with her Afro in full confidence, while people stare in admiration!Akima Paul Lambert Paige Lewin Paulette Watson MBA Global Tech Disruptor Tashara Parker, MA Emmanuel Asuquo - TV Financial Adviser Patti O'Brien-Richardson, PhD D.
